articles.headline: After Bribery Scandal, High-Level Departures at Walmart
articles.snippet: At least eight senior executives have left the giant retailer since reports of bribery in its international division surfaced two years ago.
articles.abstract: At least eight senior executives have left the giant retailer since reports of bribery in its international division surfaced two years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thomas A. Mars, formerly the chief administrative officer for Walmart in the United States, stepped down. José Luis Rodríguezmacedo Rivera, once the general counsel at Walmart’s Mexican division, quietly left the company. And H. Lee Scott Jr., who was Walmart’s chief executive, will retire from the board this month.

articles.headline: A Gas Cache, Now Under Shaky Ground
articles.snippet: The Groningen field in the Netherlands has provided energy for decades, but a series of earthquakes have damaged property and rattled residents.
articles.abstract: The Groningen field in the Netherlands has provided energy for decades, but a series of earthquakes have damaged property and rattled residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOPPERSUM, the Netherlands — Deep below the cow pastures and farming villages in this picturesque northeastern corner of the Netherlands lies an extraordinary resource: Europe’s largest source of natural gas, known as the Groningen gas field.

articles.headline: T-Mobile and Sprint Zeroing In on a $32 Billion Merger
articles.snippet: A deal, long contemplated, would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States: Verizon and AT&T.
articles.abstract: A deal, long contemplated, would create a more formidable rival to the two largest wireless phone providers in the United States: Verizon and AT&T.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:51 p.m. | Responding to a wave of consolidation in the telecommunications industry, the nation’s third- and fourth-largest wireless phone operators have agreed on the terms of a deal to join forces.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: British Bank Regulators Pine to Win a Big Case
articles.snippet: Stung by missteps and losses, the Serious Fraud Office, which prosecutes and investigates corruption and fraud, is struggling to improve its track record.
articles.abstract: Stung by missteps and losses, the Serious Fraud Office, which prosecutes and investigates corruption and fraud, is struggling to improve its track record.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Credit Suisse agreed on May 19 to plead guilty and pay $2.6 billion for conspiring to help Americans avoid taxes, it was yet another day of dreary headlines for bankers around the world.

articles.headline: Democrats See a Break in a Gain for the Tea Party in Mississippi
articles.snippet: The strong showing of the sometimes-unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel, in the Republican primary offered Democrats the opportunity to highlight his controversial views.
articles.abstract: The strong showing of the sometimes-unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel, in the Republican primary offered Democrats the opportunity to highlight his controversial views.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is a major headache for the national Republican Party and perhaps the biggest break Democrats have been handed in this difficult election year: a three-week runoff campaign in Mississippi between a party elder, Senator Thad Cochran, and the sometimes unpredictable Tea Party favorite, Chris McDaniel.

articles.headline: Behind P.O.W.’s Release: Urgency and Opportunity
articles.snippet: An Obama administration divided over a prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders swept those issues aside in the rush to secure Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
articles.abstract: An Obama administration divided over a prisoner swap that would free five Taliban commanders swept those issues aside in the rush to secure Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Weeks before a Black Hawk helicopter lifted off in the dying light of eastern Afghanistan, carrying with it an American soldier who had spent five years in the hands of the Taliban, American officials grew increasingly worried that Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s life might be in jeopardy.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt, David E. Sanger and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: European Central Bank Breaks New Ground to Press Growth
articles.snippet: The central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 0.15 percent, a record low.
articles.abstract: The central bank cut its benchmark interest rate to 0.15 percent, a record low.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Banks typically make money on the cash they park at a central bank. Now the European Central Bank wants them to pay for the privilege.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: G.M. Inquiry Cites Years of Neglect Over Fatal Defect
articles.snippet: In an internal investigation, the company cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to deal with a fatal ignition flaw, and said 15 had been dismissed.
articles.abstract: In an internal investigation, the company cited bureaucratic problems and the failure of individual employees to deal with a fatal ignition flaw, and said 15 had been dismissed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARREN, Mich. — A sweeping internal investigation of General Motors released on Thursday condemned the company for its decade-long failure to fix a deadly safety defect, one that led to “devastating consequences,” including at least 13 deaths.
